fields.summary: Ability to display and search/filter on assigned teams in JIRA
Team member availability to automatically reflect public holidays based on their/system locale

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1858].
  {panel}

Now, it is only possible to filter in Portfolio on open and closed issues. I'd like to see that I can filter on any status/statuscategory a ticket is in.

The reason for this is that we have a status called "To Write", "To Refine" and "Ready for Build". The PO works in Portfolio and wants to be able to have a quick overview of everything that still needs to be written or refined.

So, the user story is:

As a product owner I want to be able to filter on issue status and status category so that I can have a quick overview of all stories in a specific status

*Acceptance Criteria*
 * Filter is added in schedule navigation of Portfolio
 * Filtering is possible on individual status
 * Filtering is possible on status category
 * Schedule overview is updated according to filter
fields.summary: Add filter for issue status
Allow exceptions for a team member to be handled with negative hours

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1860].
  {panel}

It seems I can change the rank of an Epic from within the Scope of a Portfolio plan - this is don't by selecting 'epic' and dragging an epic up or down relative to the other epics. This changes the relative rank of the epics.

 

What doesn't appear to happen though, is any change to the rank of the child stories. I would expect that if I dragged a epic above another one, then it's enclosing stories should now rank higher than the stories of the epic that is now ranked lower.

Is that supposed to work, or are there any tool sets I can use to make that happen?

It seems difficult to sync the schedule suggested by Portfolio back onto a board, so that the priorities set in the schedule affect the order of work that is picked up from the board (in a Kanban style).

 

Am I missing something?
fields.summary: Changes to Rank of an Epic don't change the Rank of their child Stories.
Colour options for Cross-project releases in the schedule

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1358].
  {panel}

In a certain user case, we use the story points field on the epic to provide us with a rough estimate of the work that the epic is going to take. Let's call this 100 pts.
We then would break down the epic into the user stories to fulfil the epic, we'll call this 75pts as the sum of the stories under the epic.

Portfolio would show us a total of 175 pts for the epic, the sum of the epic including the sum of the children. The scenario we were expecting was to see the sum of just the children at 75, and we'd be able to use JQL to calculate based off the estimate of 100 we only planned 75, so we overestimated by 25pts.

What we would like is at each level, to have an estimate field in portfolio that will be stored on the individual tickets as well as the actuals.
We're looking to be able to baseline Initiatives, Epics, and Stories with their original estimates as well as the actuals.
fields.summary: Ability to have an estimate field that can be stored on the individual tickets as well as the actuals

fields.description: As I go through planning, I sometimes decide that an epic really isn't part of the scope of the current plan, so I'd like to remove it from the plan. However, to do this currently I have to go through and re-import all the data. Am I doing this incorrectly, or is it really this difficult?
fields.summary: I want to be able to mark an issue as out of scope so that I can simplify my project

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1769].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
At the moment, allowing user/group to be part of "Portfolio for JIRA Viewer" permission in Global permission will allow the user to have access to all Live plans. 

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow the setting of Live plans' Viewers permission to be set for certain user/group though they are not part of "Portfolio for JIRA Viewer" permission.

h3. Why this is important
Certain users/groups are limited to seeing projects. Having listed all plans under "View All Plans" allow them to view them but seeing empty issues there due to not having a full "Browse Projects" permission to the projects.

h3. Workaround
Set *both* Viewer and Editor plan-specific permission to a value. This will take precedence over Global permission.
fields.summary: Limit user view of plans
You must add a zoom to see information about an issue

fields.description: I would like to permanently disable the Classic Plans message in Portfolio because March has long passed, and it takes up half of the screen.
fields.summary: As a user, I want to disable the Potfolio Classic plans message
Ability to show custom fields in scope section
Portfolios - Clone/copy

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-521].
  {panel}

Dear Martin Suntinger,

You may recall that we - briefly - exhanged ideas/opinions earlier this month on the subject of JIRA Portfolio.

Our evaluation has now been completed and our project manager, Gert Pedersen, has submitted his report to our Confluence "Wiki" instance - pls. see the attached PDF.

As you will note, the recommendation, and the following decision, was not to license JPO at the moment.

I'm sending you the evaluation report to ensure that you know exactly what triggered the outcome. I trust you can use the content, not just to dismiss our quaint ways of working ;-), but also for improving the product going forward.

If you have any questions, please comment on this ticket.

In any case, I'll be attending the Summit next November, should the need arise for us to have further interaction.

Cheers,

Lasse
fields.summary: JIRA Portfolio Evaluation - Pls. forward to Martin Suntinger

fields.description:
When an issue is displayed on the chart which spans across a weekend or a non-working day, currently Portfolio displays the issue as if it is being worked through the weekend. For an issue with two days scheduled where day 1 is on a Friday and day 2 is on a Monday, the chart will span the issue through Saturday and Sunday as well if they are non-working days.

This can lead to confusion, because it can make a two-day issue look like a four-day issue. It would be great if non-working days were indicated on the chart, because that would make it clear at a glance when issues span a weekend. Additionally colorizing these periods of time would make it easier to identify the passage of weeks during the span of a project, which provides more context to the chart.
fields.summary: Colorize Weekends and Non-Working Days Differently on The Chart
Allow releases to be grouped into cross-project releases
Bulk Update for Releases, Teams, and Themes Columns in Scope

fields.description:
h3. The Matter
Currently, some teams use labels to define groups that will attack certain issues or tasks inside a sprint. 

h3. The proposal
It would be nice to add a filter to our Plans so we could filter plans according to labels on issues.
fields.summary: Allow administrators to plan based on issue's labels
Highlight whole dependency chains (Live Plans)
using "Due Date" of ticket as "Target end" on Portofolio Plan
Add Epic Due Date in JIRA Portfolio

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, the Portfolio Scheduling algorithm is showing the *Start* and *End* date of the issues the same as the Sprint *Start* and *End* date. 

h3. Suggested Solution
Customers would want to have the *Start* and *End* date for the issues calculated as well
fields.summary: Schedule issue Start and End date within the Sprint

fields.description:
Hi all, 

I notice that, when I group by project on the scope view, the name of my project is not visible. 

Is it possible to make it visible (or may also be a good feature a mouseover on the project's name) ? 

 

Thanks 

Dania
fields.summary: Grouping by project

fields.description:
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Prepare epic1 and epic2
 # Set the duration as the following
 ** epic 1: 1 day
 ** epic 2: 3 days
 # Create a release to include the two epics and set the due date to a future date

h3. Expected Results

User will be able to dynamically set the start day as "due date minus four days".
h3. Actual Results

The current option is the following and user isn't able to create a future plan dynamically.
 * Fixed start date
 * Relative to previous release date
 * As early as possible
fields.summary: Set start dates dynamically based on due date

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Currently, Portfolio only allows the option to create a new Cross-Project Release but there is no way to take an existing Release and converting it into a shared release.

h3. Proposed feature

In the *Releases* add a *share this release* option to convert it into a Cross-Project Release that will automatically add the Release to the concerned Projects in JIRA.
fields.summary: Convert existing releases to a cross-project release

fields.description:
When Portfolio is unable to schedule the issues on the existing sprints from Jira, them new Sprints will be created only on Portfolio side. 

I want to have the ability to disable this feature.
fields.summary: As a user/project manager, I want to have the ability to disable the Portfolio's created Sprints

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
In Jira, users are not able to search for issues in *Parent link* field if users have only plan view and edit permissions. If users are given *Portfolio user* global permission they are able to search for issues in parent link.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# In Jira, add *parent link* field to an issue screen.
# In Portfolio, create a plan and add a user to a group that has Editors and Viewers permission.
# Make sure that the user is not added to any of the groups that have *Portfolio User* permission.
# Now when the user tries to search for issues in *Parent link* field, it throws an error message *You are not authorized to perform this operation. Please login*


h3. Expected Results
User should be able to search for issues in parent link field as the user is added to Editor and Viewer plan permissions in Portfolio

h3. Actual Results
An error message is shown stating that the user doesn't have permissions to perform the operation.

h3. Workaround
The workaround is to add users to one of the groups that have *Portfolio user* permission.

*Notes*: Users are able to link the issue from the portfolio end by navigating to the issue in the plan and are also able to commit the changes. Also, the changes made in the portfolio plan reflects in the Jira issue. 

h3. Proposed solution

Allow users to search for issues in *Parent link* field without needing the *Portfolio user* Global permission
fields.summary: Users are not able to search for issue in parent link with edit plan permission in Portfolio

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1467].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently it is not possible to display epic priorities in Portfolio in the same way they are displayed in JIRA and vice versa. This is due to the fact that in JIRA all issues are ranked in a “flat” manner: you can have sub-tasks before parents and stories before epics, etc when you search for issues. In Portfolio, issues are displayed based on hierarchy and as such, they cannot be ranked in the same manner as those in JIRA.  
h3. Suggested Solution
Provide a way to import these priorities and hierarchies between Portfolio and JIRA, so that they can also be viewed in JIRA. 

h3. Workaround 
A possible workaround would be to change the order of your stories in JIRA based off how you would like your Epics ranked.
fields.summary: Mirror epic priorities between JIRA and Portfolio

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1872].
  {panel}

At the moment you have Scope, Teams, Releases perspectives in Portfolio.

However, there is no Resoruce (People) perspective. 

In Consulting business it is important to always know if a resource (consultant) is fully booked, or is there available capacity.

It is not possible currently to see capacity of a single person, if he is assigned to several teams. You need to manually look this person up in each team.
fields.summary: Resource Perspective

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1411].
  {panel}

*Description:*
Actually, in Portfolio the order of epics in the hierarchical view depends on its child story ranks and do not necessarily reflects the ranks of the epics to each other.

*Suggested Solution:*
A flat list for epics and stories sorted by their rank, which would make it possible to see the actual rank of an epic and also to re-rank an epic on its own.
fields.summary: Show Epics and Stories also in a flat list
Capacity Views in Live Plans
Improve speed of completing updates in Portfolio

fields.description: As a Confluence user, I would like the ability to limit users in my space to edit pages but not create new pages, so that I can maintain a strict page naming and hierarchy standard.
fields.summary: Confluence Page-level Security Enhancement: Add Edit Only Rights

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1878].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently, in [Creating and configuring cross-project releases|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfoliocloud/creating-and-configuring-cross-project-releases-828785313.html] it is not clear in the documentation how users can add existing releases to Cross project release 

h3. Suggested Solution
Improve the documentation with: 
The CPR is basically a grouping over individual releases, thus you can create new release add it to an existing CPR. To do so:
# Create a new *Single release* for the project in the plan (or in the project)
# Click on the CPR name, which will show the details page
# Click *Add release* button, to add existing release.

Note that you can only have one release from a project in the CPR.
fields.summary: Improve documentation about cross project releases

fields.description:
h3. Problem Description

As mentioned in [3 new features in Portfolio|https://www.atlassian.com/blog/jira-software/ew-features-portfolio-for-jira-2-2], Portfolio introduces a new column/feature called _Original Story Points_. The problem is it's only visible in Portfolio but not in Jira.

h3. Suggested Resolution

Make Original Story Points field available/visible in Jira
fields.summary: Make Original Story Points field available/visible in Jira

fields.description:
Hi Atlassian,

 

Could you build in a feature to have the releases defined in Portfolio colored in the Portfolio schedule. 

As releases are the most important part we communicate with our stakeholders we have seen that it gives them an extreme confidence in our planning when we show what tickets are being picked up for a release; using colors have been proved very effective.

In the attachment you see a example where we abuse themes at the moment to achieve the same result to color the releases for our stakeholders.
fields.summary: Have the ability to give releases a color that is reflected in the schedule of Portfolio
Replicate Theme field from Portfolio to JIRA Issue

NIladri

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1786].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Description

User has the following scenario:
# Within one plan, there is a team with 2 members
# There is a single Sprint in the plan.
# 1 Story with 2 hours estimation and its 3 Subtask (A, B and C) with 1 hour estimation each

When users visit Capacity report, Portfolio assign 4 hours to user one and 1 hour to user two. 

As a user, I'd like to have Portfolio to assign the issues equally to each of the member so it will be like 3 hours to user one and 2 hours to user 2.

h3. Suggested Resolution

Provide an option to make Portfolio to assign planned capacity equally for all team members.
fields.summary: Assign planned capacity equally for all team members

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, the Theme report cannot be used to show the issues in a given Sprint that are also in a given Theme and are open/closed.
The Actual chart is only used to reflect the estimates of completed issues in the Plan, but it would be useful if this would show the issues scheduled for a given Sprint, for example.
h3. Suggested Solution
Create another report similar to this one that will have the completed and open work presented in the graph for a given Sprint.
fields.summary: Extend the Theme Report, or create another report like this, to report on completed and open work

N/A

fields.description:

h3. Suggested Solution

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1714].

*Problem*

With long running projects, certain versions that were part of my plan will get archived over time. Consequently, the issues associated with these versions will not show up in the plan anymore (issues assigned to versions hidden from the plan do not show up). I would like to be able to have an option for showing archived versions of a plan, and along with them, the respective issues assigned to them

*Expected behaviour*

Show issues with archived versions and exclude rules can be configured if needed

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, when there is a release selected, the capacity view shows as free capacity, even though the capacity is allocated for another release. 

For example:
# There are 2 releases and 2 team members.
# One team member is assigned to issues from *Release R1* and the other team member to issues from *Release R2*.
# The team Velocity is 30.
# The capacity view shows 15 (full capacity) for each of the members.
#*  !Planned capacity.png|thumbnail!  
# When the one release is selected, the capacity view shows *Free Capacity* for this team member
#*  !Free capacity.png|thumbnail!  

h3. Suggested Solution
Add information about planned capacity from not selected views.

My Initiative's release is set to Calculate, however one of the children within it was set to a manual release of VerifierUX1 (one of my releases). I couldn't figure out why my Initiative was calculating to VerifierUX1 when i had it collapsed, because it was blue.

When i expanded, i understood i had forced my story's release and it was white. It would be better if the Initiative showed 50% blue 50% white (or some other indicator) that said the epics and children below are a mixture.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
On Advanced Roadmaps parent tickets (e.g.: Epics) have no estimation when the estimation is done on lower levels

h3. Suggested Solution
Parent tickets should sum its children estimates

h3. Workaround 
N/A
fields.summary: On Advanced Roadmaps, the parent tickets should include the sum of it's children estimates

fields.description:
As an executive who views Portfolio reports, I want to see how much of my teams efforts are being spent on different focus areas (themes) for my upcoming release. The teams have the same Sprint cadence and the release date is fixed, such that all teams have to release to our customers at the same time. The Sprint lasts for 2 weeks, and the release cycle consists of 3 Sprints (6 weeks). Each team member works for 40 hours a week.

The teams have different Velocities; Pineapples Team (5 people) deliver 20 points a Sprint and Grapes Team (also 5 people) deliver 200 points a Sprint. The teams are working on different focus areas; both are equally important to our customers, and based upon the team's estimates will take the entire release to deliver. As such the target for each theme is set to 50% each.

Currently, the estimate shows that ~91% of focus will be spent on Grapes theme, ~9% of focus will be spent on Pineapples as the report blindly adds Story points and treats them all as equal when they are not (and never should be considered in that way!)

What we need is to take into account both the estimates on the Epics/Stories/Tasks and the team velocity, in order to be able to compare apples to apples and look at the focus (themes) across the whole projects.
fields.summary: Improvement for Portfolio Themes Report.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1510].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Description

When a board contains multiple parallel active Sprints, Portfolio only imports _one_ active Sprint per board and there is no way or option to select which Sprint to be imported. It also does not allow sprints to overlap in any way, even if the start date of one sprint takes place before the end date of another.

h3. Suggested Resolution

Provide an option to select which active Sprint to be imported from a board, and allow Portfolio to recognize and take advantage of the parallel sprints functionality, as right now it does not seem to know how to handle them properly.
fields.summary: Provide a feature to select an active Sprint from a board
If dependency is at parent level this should be displayed on children issues and vice versa
Ability to set stage of work when logging time

fields.description:
h3. Scenario

When grouping issues by Components on the Plan, if any issues do not have a component, the higher hierarchy are incorrectly displayed showing *Issues without parent XXXXX*.
!Screen Recording 2019-03-27 at 05.03 PM.gif! 

h3. Suggestion

Display the parent initiative name on the *Issues without components* section of the plan.
fields.summary: When grouping issues by Components on the Plan, if any issues do not have a component, the higher hierarchy are incorrectly displayed

fields.description: Teams and people pages only show the first 50 teams and 100 people that match the provided search string. Further refinement of the search is required to get to the desired team or person. To improve this experience, paging or infinite scrolling should be introduced to allow browsing through all existing teams or persons.
fields.summary: Provide either paging or infinite scrolling to team management's team and people pages
Add dependencies in Live plans

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1678].
  {panel}

*Story:* As a C-Level leader, I want a flexible, intuitive chart view at the highest level cross-team initiatives, so that I can selectively expand/collapse any initiative to understand the work, teams, epics and blockers within it.

*Details:*
* Full screen view showing a bar chart with the name of the top level initiative and agile timeline spanning number of sprints (based on anticipated velocity, exactly as Portfolio currently calculates), with possible dates overlaid if relevant. 
* Ability to selectively click into each initiative to dive into the component Epics, then stories, subtasks, etc... (entire hierarchy)
* Clear view of blocking/blocked issues, with indicators (lines?) to what is blocking/blocked by it. 
* Clear coloring of issues either by status, or ideally by custom configuration (along the lines of card color logic available on Agile Boards)

*Problem this is solving* 
* Current view makes you choose the overall level (Story Level, Epic Level, etc...), which in larger engineering companies (30+ teams working on large cross-team initiatives) quickly makes it unusable
* Alternate view within current Portfolio is by Project, which doesn't cover the cross-team dependencies that emerge in larger setups or when building a micro-services environment (teams for Database/API/etc... that will play smaller roles in many different projects)
* Current blocking implementation is harder to see (slighter shaded blue) and doesn't indicate what it is actually blocking until you click on it. When you have dozens of relationships like this, that become impractical quickly to visualize where your problems are in the pipeline. 
* The biggest alternate portfolio products on the market show views like this, but can't handle the Agile/iterative/points component of the equation. Jira Portfolio DOES handle that piece, and building an agile version of this view becomes a clear delineator in the market. 

*Note:* For the sake of my examples, calling the highest-level issue type _Initiative_, please substitute as needed.
fields.summary: Create Agile Gantt-Like Chart for Portfolio

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1833].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently, there is an "Original Story Point" estimate field which allows customers to 
The scheduling algorithm, however, ignores this column. 

The customer would want to have a field named for example "Target Story Points" and be able to check the plan for it

h3. Suggested Solution
Add a "Target Story Points" field and possibility to calculate a plan based on it


h3. Workaround 
-
fields.summary: Add "Target Story Points" field and possibility to calculate the plan based on its value

fields.description: When creating a plan by using a filter as a source, if the filter has an ORDER BY statement, the plan should no longer allow re-ordering, but keep the order dictated by the source filter
fields.summary: plan should not allow reordering if source is a filter with ORDER BY statement

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1453].
  {panel}

Hello,

In ancient Portfolio version we have the possibility to monitor/see also past releases (which, by experience, sometimes for the user is useful). 
Do you think would be possible to display, in future releases of Portfolio Live Plans, past releases as well?

Thank you very much!
fields.summary: Historical data available generating a Live Plan

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1551].
  {panel}

*Problem*
Scheduling treats dependencies between issues in a way that blocked issues will be held back until the blocking issue was scheduled. This basically means that the blocked issue virtually gets "ranked" below the blocking issue (unless the rank order already matches the dependency order, i.e., the blocked issue has a lower rank than the blocking one). In certain situations (like two teams working on de facto independent backlogs) this behaviour leads to unintuitive / unexpected outcomes.

*Solution*
In order to allow scheduling to better adjust to the particular setup, an option to change this behaviour should be introduced. I want to be able to "pull up" blocking issues above my blocked issue to keep it from being scheduled later. Alternatively I would like scheduling to ignore dependencies and just have them visualized.
fields.summary: Allow to configure how Portfolio handles dependencies in scheduling

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1640].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Description

JIRA Portfolio doesn't currently have a feature to print a report hence users will have to use the browser feature (pressing Ctrl+p) to workaround it. However, when _Schedule report_ contains a lot of projects, the workaround is no longer working as it only prints/shows a single page.

h3. Suggested Resolution

Provide a feature to print the report.
fields.summary: A feature to print Portfolio report
Ability to move stories easily from sprint to sprint in Portfolio plan itself
Allow addition of new heirarchy levels that are not associated with JIRA issue types
Projected dates from Portfolio plans should be visible in JIRA

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1529].
  {panel}

This hierarchy below is an example of a higher level being added to the default hierarchy:
!hierarchy.PNG|thumbnail! 

I would like to be able to add a level below stories and remove sub-tasks. The reason for this is that stories can be used to represent requirements, but may or may not be able to be completed in a sprint. I would like to test these requirements via manual and automated testing at some point when they are finished, and complete tasks in sprints. 

JIRA doesn't deal we well with having items span multiple sprints, so I would like the tasks to be the work items completed sprint to sprint. This use case assumes a story isn't a product increment that can be finished in a sprint, but a goal or deliverable that will be worked through over time. For example, a slow infrastructure build, that isn't following agile manifesto, but is benefiting from some agile features.
fields.summary: Allow removing of sub-tasks in hierarchy and adding of lower levels

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1864].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently, selecting the scope filter by completion date the completed issues are shown, but also the open issues.
*  !Completed since.png|thumbnail!

The customer would want to see *only* the completed issues in the selected period

h3. Suggested Solution
Show only completed issues 
 
h3. Workaround 
-
fields.summary: Scope filter Completed should only show completed issues

fields.description:
Ideally we would have horizontal swimlanes for each of our themes in the timeline / roadmap view. This would enable us to show which initiatives/epics are advancing which themes. Currently I can only see per project(?)

If this is already possible, I'd love to be shown how!!
fields.summary: Allow Roadmap to be grouped by theme

fields.description: As a Portfolio user, I want to be able to export the weekly hours capacity of the teams.
fields.summary: As a Portfolio user, I want to be able to export the weekly hours capacity of the teams

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1417].
  {panel}

If I have one person on two projects (frequently...) and change the Schedule Settings to group by person, they are first grouped by project.

Project A
- Joe Bob <Issue>
- Betty Sue <Issue>

Project B
- Joe Bob <Issue>

Project C
- Betty Sue <Issue>

What I expected to be able to do was show something like the list below to visualize cross-project assignment and capacity issues.

Joe Bob
<Project A issue>
<Project B issue>

Betty Sue 
<Project A issue>
<Project C issue>
fields.summary: Grouping by Person displays "By Person By Project".
Allow sharing Themes between plans
Draft plan edits should be scoped to the individual until committed

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1546].
  {panel}

As a Jira Portfolio-Admin, i want an additional JQL-filter for the issue source "Board". So i can define, which issues are imported automatically.

*Description:*
We use a board as an issue source but there are some issues we want to hide in our portfolio plan.
When we use an extra filter (instead of the board) as the issue source, the sprint-informations are not imported!
fields.summary: Additional filter for the issue source "Board"
Ability to Export individual projects to .csv

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1846].
  {panel}

h1. Story

As a Product Manager, I want to be able to filter by Initiative or Epic, in order to help frame discussion and presentation when diving into Epic and Story view.
h1. Expansion

As my team get's deeper into Portfolio, we have multiple Product Mangers interacting with the same Plan. While we can drive high-level engagement using the Portfolio plan, it becomes a less useful when I want to focus on a specific Initiative, it's components or deliverables, as I can't provide a specific view.

This is especially obvious when I have more than one project which contributes to the same Initiative, and I'm engaging in focused project reviews with stakeholders.
fields.summary: Filter by Initiative & Epic

fields.description: Placeholder description
fields.summary: As a Product Owner, I want to see all releases of a plan by date
Define different stages and skills % for individual issue sources in a plan.
Add to the documentation the number of issues that a plan should be limited to.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The Portfolio allows plans with up to 5000 issues but in the "Confirm what's in scope" the message "There are too many issues to load them all individually" if the issue source has more than 2000 issues. 

h3. Environment

* Jira Software cloud
* Portfolio for Jira cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Create one project and add 2500 issues to it
# Create a new Portfolio plan and select this project as an issue source 
# In the plan's configuration, when accessing the screen "Confirm what's in scope", try to expand an Epic view or the "Issues without parent Epic" panel

h3. Expected Results

All issues below Epic are displayed

h3. Actual Results

The message "The next level of the hierarchy is currently disabled. There are too many issues to load them all individually. Please use filters to narrow down the data set first"

 !Screen Shot 2019-08-29 at 9.51.42 PM.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Notes

This affects only the "Confirm what's in scope" view, the plan works.

h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: The "Confirm what's in scope" view should allow to more than 2000 issues per hierarchy level when creating a plan in Portfolio
Having the option for the user to re-order/re-arrange column in JIRA Portfolio

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1039].
  {panel}

At the moment, if we have an estimated epic that has estimated child stories...

- The estimate column displays the sum of children's estimates.
- The progress column displays the sum of the children's estimates, *plus* the estimate that is directly on the epic.

This can be somewhat confusing, so it might be better if the progress column displayed the same value as the estimate column.
fields.summary: Epic estimate summation should be consistent between estimate column and progress column

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Currently the scope table aggregates values from child issues for display, for example if there was an Epic 'epic' with two children configured with:
* Child A - Theme 1
* Child B - Theme 2

Then on the Epic Theme 1 and Theme 2 would both be shown. The same behaviour will apply for releases and other values in the scope table as well.

If one of the children is hidden by a filter then its values will not be aggregated. Taking the above example if Child B was hidden by a filter then the Epic would only show Theme 1.

This suggestion would change that behaviour so that aggregate values from child issues are always visible, even if the child issue itself is hidden by a filter.
fields.summary: Aggregated values from child issues should be displayed when child is hidden by filter
